info: The filing reports equity component amounts (common stock, additional paid‑in capital, retained earnings, treasury stock, accumulated other comprehensive income) each recorded as 6951, and also lists minimum and maximum values for various asset categories (building improvements, equipment, software development costs, furniture and fixtures) all equal to 6951.
Company disclosed a series of unsecured senior notes with rates ranging from 1.75% to 5.85% and maturities spanning 2025 to 2050, reflecting a diversified long‑term debt structure.

The filing reports multiple equity‑based compensation and tax‑related items, each recorded at 6,951, covering performance shares, RSUs, employee stock purchase plan, deferred compensation, valuation allowance, tax credit carryforwards, research carryovers, and other non‑current liabilities.

Applied Materials highlighted its position as a leader in semiconductor materials engineering, operating Semiconductor Systems and Applied Global Services segments; AGS’s 200 mm equipment line will be transferred to Semiconductor Systems in Q1 FY2026. The company serves a broad range of end‑markets including AI, IoT, automotive and clean energy, and emphasizes its comprehensive product portfolio spanning patterning, packaging and process control.

The company highlights its advanced patterning, process control, and advanced packaging technologies aimed at 3D transistors and heterogeneous integration, serving semiconductor markets including leading‑edge (≤7nm) and non‑leading‑edge nodes. The Applied Global Services (AGS) segment, which provides spares, services, and factory automation software, will absorb the 200 mm equipment business in Q1 FY2026. Backlog as of Oct 26 2025 totals $15.0 billion, with roughly half in each of the Semiconductor Systems ($7.1 b) and AGS ($7.1 b) segments; 31% of the backlog is not expected to be filled within 12 months, indicating longer‑term revenue exposure. Customer concentration is notable, with two customers representing about 19% and 15% of net revenue. The firm underscores ongoing R&D investment, a portfolio of over 23,500 active patents, and exposure to competitive and regulatory risks, including potential increased competition from Chinese equipment makers and export controls. Workforce stands at ~36,500 employees, heavily weighted toward Asia‑Pacific (46%).

The filing highlights several material risks: cyclical semiconductor demand and uncertainty around AI‑driven growth; exposure to global economic volatility, trade restrictions, tariffs and export‑license challenges—especially in China, Taiwan and Korea; a highly concentrated customer base outside the U.S.; supply‑chain disruptions, component shortages and potential geopolitical events; and ongoing government subpoenas related to export‑control compliance. Leadership tenure and ages are noted, reflecting experienced management but also an aging executive team.

The company highlights extensive supply chain vulnerabilities—including global trade tensions, semiconductor component shortages, rare‑earth export restrictions slated for 2025, and geopolitical disruptions—plus heightened cybersecurity, AI, intellectual‑property, and government‑incentive compliance risks; it stresses the critical dependence on the semiconductor systems segment, competitive pressures, and challenges associated with expanding into new markets and technologies.

The filing highlights extensive risks tied to acquisitions, investments, and divestitures, including integration challenges, regulatory approvals, potential impairment of goodwill, and increased debt. It notes significant tax law changes—global minimum tax, the U.S. OBBBA, and expiring Singapore reduced rates—that could raise effective tax rates. Debt exposure includes $6.5 billion of senior unsecured notes and a $4.1 billion revolving credit facility, with a 101% repurchase price trigger on change‑of‑control. The company also emphasizes cybersecurity, regulatory compliance, employee retention, and sustainability obligations as material risk factors.

The company emphasizes robust cybersecurity governance with Board and Audit Committee oversight and quarterly reporting, while managing a global portfolio of approximately 9.1 million owned and 5.3 million leased square feet plus 279 acres of buildable land. It reported 2,626 registered common stock holders and continues an aggressive share repurchase program authorized for $20 billion, with $14 billion remaining and $856 million repurchased in Q4 FY2025 across three months. Management highlights strategic focus on RD&E, expanding service subscriptions, and notes ongoing export regulation and trade tariff risks affecting China and other markets.

Revenue rose 4% to $28.4 billion in FY2025, driven by growth in Semiconductor Systems and Applied Global Services, with gross margin improving to 48.7% and operating income increasing, while net income fell modestly. Ongoing U.S. export controls and higher tariffs on China create trade risk. Geographic mix shifted: China revenue down 16% and U.S. down 20%, while Korea, Taiwan and Asia‑Pacific revenues rose sharply. Semiconductor Systems remained the dominant segment (~73% of revenue) and its product mix shifted toward logic/foundry and flash memory.

Fiscal 2025 saw higher RD&E and marketing spend, lower G&A, a $41 million goodwill impairment and $181 million restructuring charge as the company plans to cut ~4% of its workforce. Interest expense rose modestly while interest income fell, yielding net interest expense of $1.251 billion versus $532 million in 2024. Income tax provision jumped to $2.273 billion, pushing the effective tax rate to 24.5% (up from 12%). Segment operating income increased for Semiconductor Systems (+$398 million) but declined slightly for Applied Global Services. Total operating income grew to $8.289 billion. Cash and investments totaled $12.9 billion, with operating cash flow of $7.958 billion, while investing and financing activities used $2.782 billion and $5.977 billion respectively. The company sold $501 million of accounts receivable in 2025.

Operating cash flow was $8.0 billion in fiscal 2025, supported by strong working capital of $12.9 billion but offset by higher tax and inventory payments. The company sold $501 million of accounts receivable in 2025, repurchased $4.9 billion of stock and paid $1.4 billion in dividends, while issuing senior notes and repaying $700 million of existing notes. Credit facilities of $4.1 billion remain unused and a $4.0 billion commercial paper limit is in place with $100 million outstanding. Capital expenditures rose to $2.3 billion and investing cash outflows were $2.8 billion. Transition tax of $255 million remains payable, and investment tax credits reduced current and future tax liabilities by $233 million and $548 million respectively. Market‑risk sensitivities show a $36 million fair‑value decrease for a 100 bp rise in rates on available‑for‑sale securities, a $462 million gain for a 100 bp fall on senior notes, and a $177 million loss for a 10% adverse currency move. Overall liquidity appears sufficient for the next 12 months.

Management affirmed effective internal control over financial reporting as of October 26, 2025 with no material changes in Q4 2025; equity compensation plans show 9 million securities outstanding for exercise and 25 million available for future issuance, including 8 million shares under the employee purchase plan (1 million subject to purchase); auditors highlighted $28.368 billion net revenue for FY2025 as a critical audit matter.

The auditors highlighted revenue as a critical audit matter due to multiple streams and complex recognition policies, requiring extensive judgment and testing of internal controls. KPMG LLP, the auditor since 2004, performed procedures on design effectiveness, policy evaluation, and sample testing. The audit report dated December 12, 2025, underscores the focus on revenue assurance.

Applied Materials increased its quarterly dividend from $1.22 to $1.78 per share and continued active share repurchases, while net income remained flat around $7 billion. Operating cash flow stayed strong (~$8 billion) but cash declined in 2025 due to higher repurchases and dividend payouts. Capital expenditures rose to $2.26 billion in 2025 and modest debt borrowing resumed.

Cash tax payments rose to $1.504 billion in FY2025, higher than FY2024 ($957 million) and FY2023 ($1.006 billion), while tax refunds fell. Interest cash outflows increased to $239 million in FY2025 from $205 million in prior years. The company recorded a $41 million goodwill impairment charge in FY2025, after reporting none in FY2024 and FY2023.

Company recognizes revenue from 2‑year extended warranties ratably, taxes are presented net of remittances, R&D costs are expensed as incurred, and income tax provisions include current and deferred components with valuation allowances. It uses foreign‑currency and interest‑rate derivatives to hedge exposures and notes no material credit‑risk losses. Recent accounting standards on fair‑value measurement of restricted equity securities and segment disclosures were adopted with no material impact. EPS showed modest growth with net income around $7 billion and basic EPS near $8.6. Cash and cash equivalents totaled $7.2 billion, total liquidity $12.9 billion, with a diversified investment portfolio across cash equivalents, fixed‑income and equity securities.

Interest income from cash, equivalents and fixed‑income securities rose to $406 million in fiscal 2025 from $486 million in 2024 and $262 million in 2023, reflecting the composition of a $12.0 billion cash‑and‑investments portfolio that includes $8.0 billion cash and equivalents, $4.0 billion short‑term and long‑term investments and a maturity profile weighted toward one‑year or less ($1.275 billion) with $2.244 billion having no single maturity date. Equity investments generated a net gain of $821 million in 2025 (down to $20 million in 2024 and $27 million in 2023) with notable unrealized gains on publicly traded securities. No material credit losses were recorded. Restricted cash equivalents of $71 million (2025) and $91 million (2024) are held in money‑market funds for deferred compensation plans.

Applied Materials disclosed $71M (2025) and $91M (2024) of restricted cash equivalents tied to deferred compensation. No Level 3 fair‑value assets were measured recurrently; equity investment impairments were material only in 2023 ($121M). Long‑term senior unsecured notes rose to $6.5B principal (fair value $6.2B) in 2025 versus $5.5B/$5.1B in 2024. Foreign‑exchange contract notional amounts increased to $2.3B in 2025. The company sold $501M, $444M and $679M of accounts receivable in 2025‑2023. Contract assets grew to $281M and liabilities to $2.566B. Unsatisfied performance obligations total $1.7B, with 53% expected within 12 months. Inventories total $5.915B, and prepaid tax and expense assets rose modestly.

PPE net rose to $4.61 billion in 2025 driven by $1.2 billion of capital incentives, while depreciation expense increased to $389 million. Government incentives cut income taxes payable by $781 million and reduced R&D expense by $31 million. The company secured new $2 billion revolving credit facilities (364‑day and five‑year) with optional increases, but had no borrowings outstanding. Commercial paper capacity was raised to $4 billion, with $100 million outstanding at a 4.07% rate and 35‑day maturity, down from a 5.06% rate and 63‑day term. In September 2025 it issued $550 million of 4.0% notes due 2031 and $450 million of 4.6% notes due 2036, using part of the proceeds to retire $700 million of 3.9% notes. Total long‑term debt grew to $6.455 billion from $5.460 billion. A restructuring plan targeting a 4% workforce reduction was approved.

The company announced a fiscal 2025 restructuring plan affecting roughly 4% of its workforce, incurring $181 million in charges (including $154m severance and $27m impairments) and adjusting restructuring reserves to $165 million. It expanded its stock repurchase authorization to a total $20 billion (two $10 billion programs) with $14 billion still available, repurchasing 30 million shares in 2025 at an average $162.85 per share (cost $4.893 billion). Dividends rose to $1.4 billion in fiscal 2025. Share‑based compensation totaled $660 million in 2025 (cost of products $158m, R&D $259m, marketing $85m, G&A $166m) with $80 million tax benefits, and $947 million of compensation expense remains unrecognized over 2.4 years.

Share‑based compensation includes service‑based awards and performance‑based awards with market‑ and performance‑goal components; fair‑value assumptions use grant‑date stock prices, risk‑free rates between 3.5%‑5.5%, dividend yields up to 3.5% and volatilities around 40‑53%. For fiscal 2025 the fair value of service‑based awards ranged 134.61‑220.09 and performance‑market awards 183.40 with additional potential 0.7 million performance awards. Non‑vested equity awards declined to 9 million shares by Oct 26 2025, with weighted‑average grant‑date fair value 148.43 and aggregate intrinsic value about 2086. Employee bonus expense rose to 785 million in 2025. Deferred compensation liabilities stood at 436 million as of Oct 26 2025. ESPP issued 2 million shares each year at average prices 131.75 (2025), 147.38 (2024) and 87.75 (2023). Pre‑tax income was 9271 million in 2025, driven by 9215 million foreign earnings. Total tax provision increased to 2273 million in 2025.

Effective tax rate rose in FY2025 due to a $659 million remeasurement of Singapore deferred tax assets and a $407 million valuation allowance on CAMT credits. Singapore tax benefits were $490 million (2025), $393 million (2024) and $369 million (2023). Total effective tax rates were 24.5% (2025), 12.0% (2024) and 11.1% (2023). The company holds sizable deferred tax assets and liabilities, with net deferred tax assets of $1216 million (2025) and $2382 million (2024). Valuation allowance grew to $1049 million (2025). Unrecognized tax benefits ended at $487 million (2025) with interest and penalty liabilities of $118 million. Potential reduction of foreign unrecognized tax benefits of about $200 million is expected. Guarantees expose up to $350 million of potential future payments and $293 million of parent guarantees to banks.

Semiconductor Systems revenue grew to $20.8 B in 2025 from $19.9 B in 2024, maintaining a high gross margin (~54% vs 52.9%) and delivering $7.4 B operating income. Applied Global Services contributed $6.4 B (2025) versus $6.2 B (2024) with lower gross margins (33–34%). Corporate and Other remained small with a loss of $0.9 B each year. Total company revenue increased to $28.4 B in 2025 from $27.2 B in 2024, with operating margin modestly improving to 29.2% and capital expenditures rising sharply to $2.26 B, reflecting continued investment. Goodwill continued to rise, reaching $3.71 B.

Goodwill decreased in FY2025 due to impairment charges, partially offset by preliminary purchase accounting for a non‑material acquisition. Customer concentration remains notable with two customers accounting for roughly 19% and 15% of FY2025 net revenue (down from 12% and 11% in FY2024). Semiconductor Systems revenue is recognized at a point in time, while Applied Global Services revenue is recognized both at a point in time for tangible goods and over time (mostly within 12 months) for services. The Semiconductor Systems market mix shifted toward foundry/logic (67% in FY2025 vs 77% in FY2023) and DRAM share rose to 26% (up from 17%). Geographic revenue is diversified, with the United States contributing $3,063 million, China $8,529 million and total consolidated revenue reaching $28,368 million in FY2025, up from $26,517 million in FY2023. Long‑lived assets increased to $5,337 million in FY2025.
